summary: This document is a chain of emails between Assistant United States Attorneys and Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team regarding the logistics of reviewing physical and electronic evidence in the case US v. Maxwell. The correspondence details negotiations over the location, timing, and conditions for evidence review, including highly confidential materials such as nude images seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices. It culminates in a confirmed schedule for evidence review at 500 Pearl Street courthouse starting April 13, 2021.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C., representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is the primary defense counsel negotiating evidence review logistics with the prosecution.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense team member copied on emails regarding evidence review arrangements.

persons.name: Christian R Everdell
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP, part of Maxwell's defense team, copied on evidence review correspondence.

persons.name: Bobbi C Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on all emails regarding evidence review logistics.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in US v. Maxwell, who is to be produced by Marshals to 500 Pearl Street for evidence review with her defense team.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the source of seized electronic devices, images, and evidence from his residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

connections.description: Menninger is lead defense counsel representing Maxwell in the criminal case, negotiating evidence review access on her behalf.
Evidence seized from Epstein's residences is central to the case against Maxwell, indicating their alleged association.
Both are defense attorneys on Maxwell's legal team, coordinating on evidence review logistics.
Both are defense attorneys copied on all evidence review correspondence for Maxwell.

events.title: Start of Evidence Review at 500 Pearl Street
events.description: Confirmed start date for Ghislaine Maxwell and her defense team to review physical and electronic evidence at the 500 Pearl Street courthouse, from 9:30am to 4:30pm daily.

events.title: Defense Request to View Evidence
events.description: Laura Menninger sends formal request to prosecution to view all evidence, including highly confidential materials, sparking the logistical negotiations.

events.title: FBI Searches of Epstein Residences
events.description: FBI seized electronic devices, servers, laptops, and other physical evidence from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (courthouse where evidence review is scheduled)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Maxwell was held)
FBI Bronx warehouse (location of most physical evidence)
26 Federal Plaza, New York, NY (FBI office holding cash evidence items)
1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY (Southern District of New York U.S. Attorney's Office)
FBI downtown Manhattan office (potential location for reviewing electronic media)
U.S. Virgin Islands (location of Epstein residence searched)
keyFacts: The prosecution confirmed that Ghislaine Maxwell would be produced by U.S. Marshals to 500 Pearl Street daily from April 13, 2021, for evidence review from 9:30am to 4:30pm.
Approximately 2,100 electronic nude/partially nude images and videos seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices had not been previously disclosed to the defense and were designated 'Highly Confidential'.
Physical evidence included items seized from Epstein's residences such as plaster busts of female torsos, a stuffed dog, framed pictures, massage tables, and electronic devices.
The FBI maintained a single laptop for review of all highly confidential electronic images due to their obscene nature and restrictions on duplication.
Evidence review negotiations revealed tensions over defense access to physical evidence, permission to use electronic devices for note-taking, and the ability to photograph non-confidential items.
